summary: Internal FBI email chain discussing a FOIA lawsuit (Clemente v. FBI) regarding the release of Jeffrey Epstein-related documents, specifically the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA). The emails involve FBI personnel coordinating on whether releasing the NPA would impact ongoing investigations and determining the proper process for potential disclosure.

persons.name: Amanda
persons.context: FBI Special Agent in the New York Field Office working on Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking, listed as a contact in the email signature.

persons.name: Clemente
persons.context: Plaintiff in the FOIA lawsuit (20-cv-1527 Clemente v. FBI, et al.) seeking Epstein-related documents, specifically prioritizing the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: FOIA Request Coordination
events.description: FBI personnel discuss the FOIA request for Epstein documents, specifically the Non-Prosecution Agreement, and consider whether its release would impact ongoing investigations.

events.title: Court Status Report Deadline
events.description: FBI personnel note they have a status report due to the court the following day regarding the FOIA lawsuit Clemente v. FBI.

keyFacts: The document is an internal FBI email chain regarding FOIA lawsuit 20-cv-1527 Clemente v. FBI, et al., which seeks Epstein-related documents.
The plaintiff has specifically prioritized obtaining the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) document from the Epstein case.
FBI personnel are assessing whether releasing the NPA would impact any ongoing investigations related to Epstein and his actions.
The emails reference a prior FOIA litigation (17-cv-3956 Radar Online) where similar documents were handled under exemption 7A.

The correspondence indicates coordination between the FBI's Information Management Division and the New York Field Office, with potential involvement of EOUSA (Executive Office for United States Attorneys) regarding the NPA.
